# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Proprioception. 
- sensory receptor sensitive to position and/or movement of body part (joints, ligaments, muscles, or tendons)

- 2 classes of proprioceptors:
    - joint proprioceptors
    - muscle/tendon proprioceptors

name: 8-3-4

# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Muscle Spindles. 
- located in muscles
- stretch receptors that parallel muscle fibers
- respond to changes in muscle length, not muscle tension

---
name: 8-3-5
layout: true


# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Muscle Spindles. 
.pull-left[
- intrafusal muscle fibers connected to spindle afferent neurons and γ-motor neurons

- extrafusal muscle fibers innervated by α-motor neurons, contraction supplies muscle force

- γ motor neurons contract intrafusal fibers to regulate sensitivity of muscle spindles to contraction of surrounding extrafusal fibers
]

---
name: 8-3-6
layout: true

# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Muscle Spindles - The Monosynaptic Stretch Reflex. 
- muscle spindle stretched (lengthened)
- spindle afferent neurons provide monosynaptic input to α-motor neuron at spinal cord 
- α-motor neuron elicits reflexive contraction

---
name: 8-3-7
layout: true


# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Muscle Spindles - The Monosynaptic Stretch Reflex. 
- only known monosynaptic reflex, very fast (≅ 50 msec)

---
name: 8-3-8
layout: true

### Muscle Spindles - The Monosynaptic Stretch Reflex.

# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Golgi Tendon Organs - A Polysynaptic Reflex. 
.pull-left[
- located in tendons
- responds to increases in muscle tension, not stretch/length
- provides information to CNS regarding load on muscle, and acts as brake to prevent overly vigourous contraction
- prevents damage to muscles
- tendon is pulled by muscle contraction, activating GTO
]

---
name: 8-3-13
layout: true

# Proprioception and Reflexes
### Golgi Tendon Organs - A Polysynaptic Reflex. 
.pull-left[
- sensory nerve excites spinal inhibitory interneuron
- interneuron inhibits α-motor neuron to diminish
  contractile force

.bolder[2 synapses]
- not as fast as monosynaptic reflex
- spinal cord also sends message to higher levels of CNS
]
